label.text: Bin-Opening Cockatoos
One species of cockatoo, a type of bird native to Australia, often opens outdoor rubbish bins to access food scraps.
People often find new methods to prevent the cockatoos from opening the bins, and they share these methods with other people.

However, it usually does not take long before some cockatoos discover how to open the bins again. If these cockatoos are observed by other cockatoos, the observers soon begin to use the same methods to open bins.
Plastic snake on bin
Brick on bin
Full water bottles attached to bin
Shoes in bin hinge
A learned behaviour is one that an organism develops through experience.
In the situation described on the right, which of cockatoos and humans show learned behaviours?
only cockatoos
only humans
cockatoos and humans
neither cockatoos nor humans

A learned behaviour is one that an organism develops through experience.
Which one of the following behaviours is an example of learned behaviour in animals?
owls sleeping in the day and being active at night
ducks using their feet to swim
newborn babies crying when they are hungry
monkeys using rocks to crack open nuts
People have used several methods to stop cockatoos from opening bins.
Researchers made the following graph to compare the success of each method.
Success of method (percentage of times the method worked)
Snake
Brick
Water bottles
Shoes
Which method was the most successful?
plastic snake
brick
water bottles
shoes
Researchers are investigating a different species of bird. This species of bird lives in groups.
They want to know if learning occurs only within a group of the birds or if learning occurs across more than one group of the birds.
Which one of the following possible investigations should the researchers do to find out?
Observe several individual birds in one group.
Observe several individual birds in several groups.
Observe a single bird in one group.
Observe a single bird as it moves between groups.
Scientists conducted a study of cockatoos opening bins that included observations from 172 households for 5 years.
The results of the study were published in a scientific journal.
Which one of these explanations is the most likely reason the research was conducted with a large number of households and for for 5 years?
Scientific research should be done thoroughly and then checked by other scientists.
The study had to continue until it found a solution to the problem of bin-opening cockatoos.
Smaller and shorter studies would not be accepted for publication.
So that other scientists would know that no more research on bin-opening cockatoos was needed.
